questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have a failover cluster named Cluster1 that hosts an application named App1.

The General tab in App1 Properties is shown in the General exhibit. (Click the General tab.)

//IMG//


The Failover tab in App1 Properties is shown in the Failover exhibit. (Click the Failover tab.)

//IMG//


Server2 shuts down unexpectedly.

You need to ensure that when you start Server2, App1 continues to run on Server2.

Solution: You increase Maximum failures in the specified period for the App1 cluster role.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
TYPO in the question

""You need to ensure that when you start *Server2*, App1 continues to run on Server2.""

should be

"You need to ensure that when you start *Server1*"

Selected Answer: B
No. it is not related

Selected Answer: A
Incorrect. Prioritizing Server 2 meant that the app will continue to run on it even when Server 1 comes back as it's no longer the highest priority machine.

Selected Answer: B
Same as Question 3 and 15, why says everyone A Yes on this one. 
Its B: No. Increasing the priority is not enough. Its unticked en not mentioned about ticking the box. Very Weird question. Hopefully Microsoft doenst mean "ticked box" by saying "Increase the priority"

Selected Answer: A
May be A?
Yes is the answer

Selected Answer: B
B. No because it's unticked (same question as previously)
Answer is True - Same as question 15 and 3 in this topic questions set

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have a failover cluster named Cluster1 that hosts an application named App1.

The General tab in App1 Properties is shown in the General exhibit. (Click the General tab.)

//IMG//


The Failover tab in App1 Properties is shown in the Failover exhibit. (Click the Failover tab.)

//IMG//


Server1 shuts down unexpectedly.

You need to ensure that when you start Server1, App1 continues to run on Server2.

Solution: From the General settings, you increase the priority of Server2 in the Preferred Owners list.

Does this meet the goal?

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have a failover cluster named Cluster1 that hosts an application named App1.

The General tab in App1 Properties is shown in the General exhibit. (Click the General tab.)

//IMG//


The Failover tab in App1 Properties is shown in the Failover exhibit. (Click the Failover tab.)

//IMG//


Server1 shuts down unexpectedly.

You need to ensure that when you start Server1, App1 continues to run on Server2.

Solution: From the Failover settings, you select Prevent failback.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Again, will make no difference. There is no preferred owner selected, and the service already runs on Server2. No ticked box means the cluster will decide who is the best for the service. The failback setting would only make difference if we had a preferred node configured.

Selected Answer: A
A - Yes. make sense

Selected Answer: A
it is what it is
Repeated question, same as number 1 in this topic

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an on-premises Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) domain that contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


The domain contains the domain controllers shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You configure a site link between Site1 and Site2 and set the replication interval to 20 minutes.

At 10:00 AM, connectivity between Site1 and Site2 fails.

Administrators perform the actions shown in the following table.

//IMG//


At 10:30 AM, connectivity between Site1 and Site2 is restored.

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
OU1 was deleted at 10:20 AM. User 3 for DC2 not in OU1 at this moment.
N,N,N for me.

discussion.content:
The Answers are Correct. N,N,Y.
User1 has been removed from Group1 at 10:07 AM. So user1 is not a member any more.
User2 has a now a phone number of 444-444. it was changed at 10:25 AM.
User 3 is Deleted because OU1 was deleted at 10:25 AM and the user was part of that OU.

Correct me if im wrong.

NNY?
It means no affect even the connection is fail between 10:00 -10:30?
correct answer

Correct for me

https://serverfault.com/questions/471113/created-the-same-user-on-two-different-domain-controllers

comments.content: I believe your link shows that #2 should be Yes? User2 has been changed twice on DC1, thus when the DC's have to resolve conflicts, the object on DC1 should have a higher VersionID? That part of the sequence of events always seemed odd to me, but I believe this is the trick embedded in the question.

discussion.content: Given answer is correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Windows Server Failover Cluster (WSFQ) that has the following configurations:

• Name: App1
• Owner node: Node3
• Type: Generic Application

The General settings for App1 are shown in the General exhibit. (Click the General tab.)

//IMG//


The Failover settings for App1 are shown in the Failover exhibit. (Click the Failover tab.)

//IMG//


The Advanced Policies settings for App1 are shown in the Advanced Policies exhibit. (Click the Advanced Policies tab.)

//IMG//


For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Y, Y, N.
You can move App1 to node4 MANUALLY, as it is one of the possible nodes. 

If node3 fails, the app would failover to node4, however node4 is not on the preferred list so it would try failover to node1... But node1 is not a possible owner so it would choose the next possible AND preferred node, which is node2.

And for the last qustion, the answer is implicit on the previous; App1 would remain on Node2, and would not failback to Node3 when it was repaired.


I'm guessing the "Owner node: Node3" at the beggining of the question is just indicating the current owner, nothing else.

EXCEPT FOR MANUAL MOVING, lesson to be taken here is first check Possible Owners, if it's not there, discard the node.
Then you get only the POSSIBLE AND PREFFERRED so you know to which nodes an app would failover to.
Ex: Node4 fails, Node1 discarded (not possible owner), Node2 possible and preferred. 
Node4 fails -> Failover to Node2
Happy studying!

My version is:
Yes - you can move the resource to Node4, as it is listed as possible owner.
No - If Node3 the owner (initial part of the question), it will hand it over to Node4. A bit confusing that the screenshot is showing Node2 as the owner node. 
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/troubleshoot/windows-server/high-availability/groups-fail-logic-three-more-cluster-node-members
No - It would fail back to the most preferred Node. It would be Node1 however it is not listed as a possible owner, Node2 will be the next choice assuming it is available.

comments.content:
2. If Node3 fails, App1 will fail over to Node2 automatically.
No

The Failover tab does not specify a direct failover target, such as Node2, for App1. The General tab shows that App1 is currently running on Node2, but the preferred owners are listed in the following order: Node1, Node3, and Node4. If Node3 fails while hosting App1, the cluster will attempt to fail over to the next available preferred owner based on this list. Since Node1 is the most preferred owner, the cluster would try to move App1 to Node1 if it is available, or to Node4 if Node1 is not available. There is no explicit indication in the configuration that Node2 is the automatic failover target for App1 when Node3 fails. Thus, automatic failover to Node2 is not guaranteed.

Correct me if i am wrong, but Node 1 is not selected as a possible owner. So if Node3 fails it can't move the resource to Node1, but to the next possible and preferred owner which is Node2. 
The question is a little bit confusing because it says Owner: Node3, however the first screenshot is showing that the App is running on Node2.
0/0 is not relevant as the radio button is clearly showing immediate failback. It won't failback because Node3 is not a preferred owner.

3. If App1 automatically fails over from Node3, App1 will fail back to Node3 automatically after Node3 is repaired.
No

The Failover tab indicates that "Allow failback" is selected, with the "Failback between" setting configured to 0 and 0 hours, suggesting that failback can occur immediately or is not restricted by a specific time window. However, the General tab lists the preferred owners as Node1 (most preferred), Node3, and Node4. After App1 fails over from Node3 to another node (e.g., Node1 or Node4) and Node3 is repaired, automatic failback would prioritize the most preferred owner, Node1, if it is available. The configuration does not explicitly state that App1 will automatically fail back to Node3 specifically. Instead, failback behavior depends on the cluster’s policies and the availability of higher-preference nodes like Node1. Therefore, automatic failback to Node3 after repair is not assured.

discussion.content:
You can move App1 to Node4 manually.
Yes

The "Possible Owners" list in the Advanced Policies tab shows that Node4 is checked, indicating that Node4 is capable of hosting App1. Additionally, the General tab lists Node4 as a preferred owner (though it is the least preferred in the order: Node1, Node3, Node4). Since Node4 is a possible owner, you can manually move App1 to Node4, provided that the cluster policies and current node states (e.g., Node4 being online and operational) allow the move. Manual movement is supported by the cluster configuration.

Who can explain this question?
1 N - why?
2 N because it will fail over to note1?(most preferred)
3 N because it will return back to note1? (most preferred)

comments.content:
I would say:
Yes - you can move it to Node4, it is listed as a possible owner so nothing prevents it from moving across.
Yes - Node1 is not a possible owner, the next possible owner available is Node2.
No - Node3 is not selected as a preferred owner. Failback applies for owner nodes only.
